reviews.review_text: I didn't give it a 5 (I reserve that for page turners that are hard to put down.) This was the most enjoyable book I've read in a while. I like the writers style - not too serious, but not insulting to ones intelligence. I've found it hard to find books that fall somewhere in between; but this book does. I don't know enough to challenge any of the facts in this book,  but it was believable enough to keep me engaged. I like reading books that give me a look into different cultures. This book did that. I would read more books by this author.
Great plot and back story. The culture and history of Ghana's gold is heartfelt.  Detective Dawson is a heroe in the face of corruption. Looking forward to more Dawson adventures.

Very interesting background to murder mystery.  Had me googling for more information and what I found lined up accurately with the book.  Love Darko and this should be an interesting move for his family.  Liked the humor with his wife's family.
Haven't read this book yet, but I am sure it will meet my expectations.

I couldn't finish, or even get too far into the book.  While more than decently written, the story was dry, and the atmosphere of Africa didn't really come through for me (though maybe that's because my idea of Africa is based on living in a different part of the continent).
A good story with lots of twists and plots.
I really like his books.  They give some insight into Ghana as well as being an interesting mystery.  The relationships are good to read as well.
Another great Darko mystery. I particularly enjoyed the many issues addressed in this novel. I can't wait for the next installment.

A terrific series.  Not only are the characters, such as Darko, well done, you get a real sense of Ghana as well.  This is basically a procedural but it's not like any other you will have read, largely because of the setting.  The books can be a little slow at times but follow along and you'll understand that the pace is appropriate.  I've read them all but think this could easily be a standalone.  Try this one for a different twist.

I have to be honest - I did not read any other books in this series.  I had been told it could be a stand alone and in a lot of ways that is true.  Enough information is given about previous character relationships to be able to figure it out.  There is a lot going for this book - exotic location, interesting characters, variety of cultures.  The author does a good job at helping the reader be able to experience the environment - not just of the story but also of the characters lives.

summary:
Book 4/5 in the Darko Dawson Series

Darko Dawson, Chief Inspector in the Ghana police service, returns in this atmospheric crime series often compared to Alexander McCall Smith's The No. 1 Ladies' Detective Agency novels.

Darko Dawson has just been promoted to Chief Inspector in the Ghana Police Service—the promotion even comes with a (rather modest) salary bump. But he doesn’t have long to celebrate because his new boss is transferring him from Accra, Ghana’s capital, out to remote Obuasi in the Ashanti region, an area now notorious for the illegal exploitation of its gold mines.

When Dawson arrives at the Obuasi headquarters, he finds it in complete disarray. The office is a mess of uncatalogued evidence and cold case files, morale is low, and discipline among officers is lax. On only his second day on the job, the body of a Chinese mine owner is unearthed in his own gold quarry. As Dawson investigates the case, he quickly learns how dangerous it is to pursue justice in this kingdom of illegal gold mines, where the worst offenders have so much money they have no fear of the law.
